Doctor Benjamin Franklin, after the de-
cease of his father, returned to Boston, iii
order to paw his respects to his mother, who
resided in that city. He had been absent
some years, and at that period of life, when
the greatest and most rapid alteration IS


made in the human appearance, at a time


when the querulous voice OF the stripping


assumes the commanding tone OF the adult,


and smiling features of youth are succeeded


by the strong lines of manhood. The Doc


tor was sensible such was the alteration OF


his person, that his mother could not Know
him except bv that instinct, which 1t IS be-
lieved, can cause mothers heart TO beat


most violently in the presence ct child, and
point the maternal eve, with quick and sud
den glance, to beloved son.


To discover the existence, OF this u1Sfincl
by actual experience, the Doctor resolved
to introduce himself as a stranger, to ms
mother, and to watch, narrowly, for the
moment in which she should dicover her
son, and then to determine, with the cool
precision of the philosopher, whether that
dicovery was the effect of that instinct OF at
| fection--that intuitive love--that innate at
tachment. which is conjecturcd to cement
relatives of the same blood; and which, by


according the passions OF parent and CHILD
| like a well-tuned viol, would at the tlrs'
touch cause them to vibrate in unison and al


once evince that they were different chords
of the same instrument.

January, in the afternoon, the Doctor knock
INSTINCT.

Impartiality tends greatly to promote har-
mony in families. Hence the necessity OF
parents not manifesting any partiality to one
or more of their children. In the favored
child, it laws the foundation tor pride and
self-importance, and in the neglected one, 1t
raises Indignation if not hatred; whatever
NAV be the motives assigned for Partially,
parents must answer to the Judge OF all the
earth, for the sorrows and evils it produces,


Harmony in family will be greatly inter
rupted, should the father and mcther pursue
different systems in the management OF their
children. 1t is therefore necessary that they
adopt similar plan, otherwise one or the
other of them, and perhaps both, will lose
the esteem Of their children; obedience to
each is not to be expected, or the probabiil-
ty is, that bad habits and ihcoherent princl-
pies will be established.


In order to promote love and harmony
among children, one should not be allowed
to domineer over or tease the other. Nor
ought one to be praised at the expense OF
another. No envious comparison must DC
drawn. Children should not be allowed to
scoff at one who happens to be an offender
This practice destroys affection, and gives
rise to resentment and retaliation. lhey
should be taught to feel for one another when
in disgrace, and not be prohibited from III
terCclinp.
HARMONY IN FAMILIES.

From Broughton's letters written in Nah
rata camp, we extract the following as
noble exception amid the visianes OF a
treacherous and distin. u ahetl people.


at was in one of these battallons that an
interesting young girl was discovered, about
a twelvemonth ago, who had served IN 1t Tor
two or three years as a Sipahec; in which
capacity she had acquired the favor OF her
supr riors, and the regard OF her comr Ides,
by her quiet and inofensve behaviour and
regular attention to the duties OF her sta
ton. 1t was obs, rived that she AWAY $
dressed her own dinner, and ate 1t. ana per
formed her ablutiuns, BY herself; but not
the slightest suspicion of her sex was IN
tertained, till about the time ! menrone1, /,
when it vas discovered by the curiosity OF d
young Sipahee, who followed her when She
went to bathe After this She continued to
serve for some months, reso' 'utcly declining
the patronage of the Baee. who proposed 70
receive her into his own family, as well As
the offers of Muha Raj to promote her i'll
the corps she belonged to. The affair soon
became the subject of general conversation
in the camp; and having expressed a
strong wish to see Jerusalem or Singh, the
name by which the Indian ID Eon went, one
of our Sipahccs, who was acquainted with
her, brought her to my tent. She appeared
to be about twenty two years ofage, was We
ry fair, and. though not handsome, possess
ed most interesting countenance. she
spoke freely of her profession and her i'm
mediate situation; but betrayed neither the
affected bashfuluess nor forward boldnes'
which such situation was likely to have
produced. And let it be recorded to the
honor of every party concerned, that iron
the moment when her sex was discovered
she met only with increased respect and at
tention from her comrades; not an ndividu
al presumed to utter word that might in
suit her, or breathing doubt that could at
feet her reputation. AT length her motiv
for enlsting and remaining in the seryic
was discovered.


An only brother was confined for debt d
Bopal, and this interesting young crcatur
had the courage to enroll herself as com
mon soldier, aud afterwards persisted in ex
posing her person to the dangers and dltt1
cuties of military life, with the generou
idea of raising money sufficient to lberat
this loved relation from confinement"
A HEROINE,

before the parlor fire. Although the board
ers appeared to conhde, perfectly, in the
strangers honesty, it was not so with Mrs.
Franklin. With suspicious caution she col
lected her silver spoons, pepper box, AND
porringer, from her closet; and after secur-
ing her parlor door, by sticking fork over
the latch, carried the plate to her chamber;
charged the negro man to sleep with his
clothes Onto take the great clever to bed
with him, and to awaken and selze the va
grant at the first noise he made in attempt
ing to plunder the house. Having thus TAX
en- every precaution, she retired to bed with
her maid, whom she compelled to sleep in
her room.


Mrs Franklin rose before the sun, rous.
ed her domestics, unfastened the parlor door
with timid caution, and was agreeably sur
priscd to find her guest quietly sleeping on
his own chair. A sudden transition from ex-
tremc distrust to perfect confidence, was nat
ural. She awak encd him with a cheerful good
morning; inquired how he rested; invited him
to partake of her breakfast, which was al
ways served previous to that of her board
ers And pray sir, said the lady, as she sip
ped her chocolate, as you appear to be
stranger here, to what distant country do
you belongl !, madam, belong to the city
of PhiiQdrlhkiG. At the mention of Phiia-
phia the Doctor declared he, for the first
time, perceived any emotion in her. Phil
adelphia said she, and all the mother suf-
fused the eye: if you live in Philadelphia,
perhaps you kaow our Ben. Who madam
Why Ben Franklin--my Ben. What, said
the Doctor, is Ben Franklin the printer
your son, why, he is my most intimate
friend he and lodge in the same room.
oh God forgive me, exclaimed the old la
dy, raising her watery eyes to heaven--and
have suffered an acquaintance of my Ben
ny to sleep in this hard chair, while my
self rested on good bed


How the Doctor discovered himself to his
mother he has not informed us: but from the
above experiment, he was firmly convinced,
and was often afterwards heard to declare,
that naturaf affection does not exist.

Ye are falling to earth from your ancient domaln'


We arc shrouding her bosom in triumph again;


We are sweeping on with the wintry blast!


Yc are ruling all-but your sway cannot last
Pile ye up! pile ye up your crest OF white
As ye fall, and mingle your wreaths OF lie;
lYe are welcome, welcome to rest on the earth'
But tell us the place of your icy birth
ave come from those clouds that are ioatne on
high,


Still tlarkning the face ofthe cold blue sky'


The chill breath of winter but scattered our tram,
10 ningle anew on this earthly domain
We would gladly descend in unerring array,
But the tempests of heaven will blow us astray!
We must follow them still where'er they may
guide,
To the shade that we love OF the sunny hill side.
Like man we remain but moment below,
And are subject like him to each blast that may
blow;


Like him we ascend rejoicing on high,
To the place Of our birth in the sapphire sky. .

When Hopes fairy fingers are straylng


o,+rthe chords ofthe youthful heart,
And fancy in prospects displaying


The bliss that new years may lmpart;
When sweet feelings are ever unsprlnging,


And the pulses all ioyou,ly beat,
When each day a new treasure is bringing,


Oh. then indeed life is most sweet!
When the torch of affection Just lighted,


Burns bright on the altar Of truth,
Ere the cold, selfish world yet has blighted


One innocent feeling ofyorlth,
When earth seems a garden unfading,


When flowers cEngaround our glad feet,
When no cloud our bright heaven is shading,


Oh then indeed is life most sweet!
When the cold breath of sorrow is sweeping
Ger the chords of the youthful heart,
And the youthful eye dmmcd with strange weep
ing,


Sees the visions of fancy departs
When the bloom of young feelingis dying;
And the breast throbs with passions fierce
strife,
when our sad DAYS are wasted in signing,
Who then can find sweetness in life!
When unkindness or coldncss has faded,


The pure undeiiled light OF love,
And the lnists Of the cold world have shaded
The dreams that around our hearts move;
When earth seems wide waste OF sorrow,
No longer with bright blessings rife,
When we look but for clouds on each morrow


Who then can find sweetness in life

Some people have trick Of describing in
cidents as having happened within their
own observation, when, in fact, they were
at the time lying asleep in bed, and disturb
ing the whole house with their dormitory.-
Such is too often the character of the eve


witnesses OF the present age. Now, would
not claim personal acquaintance with an in-
cident had not seen--no, not for fifty gum
eas per sheet; and, therefore, l warn the
reader not to believe the following little


story about an eagle and child (by the way,
that is the Derby crest, and favorite sign of
inns in the north of England on the alleged


authority of the writer of this article. i
tell the tale as twas told to me- by the
schoolmaster of the parish alluded to above,


and if the incident never occurred, then must


he have been one of the greatest and most


gratuitous of liars that ever taught the


young idea how to shoot For my single


self am by nature credulous Many ex-
traerdinary things happen in this life, and


though seeing is believing so likewise 'be.


licving is seeing as every one must allow


who reads the following pages of this Mag


azine.


".llmost all the people in the parish were


leading in their meadow hay (thcrc were not
in all its ten miles aquare, twenty acres of


rye grass) on the same day of midsummer,


so driving was the sun and wind--and huged
heapcd up wains, that almost hid from view
the horses that drew them along the sward
beginning to get green with another growth,


were moving in all directions towards the


snug farm yards. Never had the parish be-


fore seemed so populous. Jocund was the


balmy air, with laughter, whistle and song.
But the Tregomers threw the shadow OF


"one O. clock" OH the green dial face of the


earth-the horses we're unyokeG and took
instantly to grazing-groups ofmen, women,

grove, and bush, and hedgerow-graces


were pronounced, some of them rather too
tedious, in presence of the mantling milk
cans, bullion bars of butter, and cracking
cakes; and the Great Being who gave them
, that day their daily food, looked down from
=, his Eternal Throne, well pleased with the
piety of his thankful creatures.


t The Great Golden Eagle, the pride and
the pest of the parish, stopped down and a.
| way with something in his talons. One sin.
. gle sudden female strickland then shout:
, and outcries as if church spire had tum
F., bled down on a congregation at sacrament
"Hannah Lamond's bairn!" Hannah La
monds bairu! !" was the loCd fast spreading


cry.-" The Eagles ta'en off Hannah La
| mopd's bairn!'' And many hundred fee
were in another instant hurrying toward
! the mountain. Two miles of hill and dale
/ and copse, and shinglc, and many intersect
2 ing brooks lay between; but in an incredi
! bly, short time the foot OF the mountain wa
. alive with people. The eyrie was vel
S known, and both the old birds were visibl
= on the rocklege. But who shall scale tina
S dizzy cliff, which Mark Steuart, the sailor
e who had been at the storming of many tort
r attempted in vain. All kept gazing, weep
n ing, wringing of hands, rooted to tn
Z: ground, or running backward and forwards
n like so many ants essaying their new wing
t in discontinue.


!: "What's the use o. ony puir huma
1t meanss We hae no power but in prayer !
j, and many knelt down-fathers and mother
t; thinking of their own babes-as It they woul
IS force the deaf heavens to hear!


Hannah Lamond had all this while bee
e sitting on rock, with face perfectly white
t. and eyes like those of mad person, tixe
d on the eyrie. Nobody had noticed her; TO
ID strong as all sympathies with her had bee
ir at the swoop of the Eagle, they were no

Look up, ye saints, with sweet surprise;
Toward the joyful coming day,
When Jesus shall descend the skies,
And form bright and dazzling ray.

iae church shall know no clouds return,
nor sorrows mixing with their JOY.

together in his peaceful reign;
ana Zion, blest with heavily bread,

me Jew, the Greek, the bond, the free,

ineir Lord, their Saviour to adore.
nus aus nil thousand years be past,
snall holiness and peace prevail;


.uev'ry knee shall bow to Christ,


ana ev'ry tongue shall Jesus hail.
Isn wa the redeem'd shall mount on high,

MILLENNIUM.

When SHOWS descend, and robe the fields


In winters bright array;


Touch'd byt the sun, the lustre fades,


And weeps itself away.


When spring appears; when violets blow,
And shed a rich perfume;


How soon the fragrance breaths its last
How short lived is the bloom!
Fresh in the morn, the summer rose
Hangs whitening ereftis noon;
Wescarce enjoy the balmy gift,
But mourn the pleasures gone.
euch are the charms that flush the cheek,
And sparkle in the eye:
Sofrom the vely-6nsh'd form,
The trancient graces fly. AN. c.

Son, and the Holy GhoSt,e and OH utterln6


these words, she few off through the heak-


ers, and over the huge stones-up-up-up


faster than ever huntsman ran into the


death-fearless as goat playing among the


precipices. No one doubted, no one could
doubt, but that she would soon be dashed to


pieces. But have not people who walk in


their sleep obedient to the mysterious guild


ance of dreams, clomb the walls of old ruins,


and found footing, even in decrepitude, along


the edge of the unguarded battlemeDts and


down dilapidated staircases, deep as draw


wells, or coal pits, and returned with open,


fixed, and unseeing eyes, unharu ed to their
beds at midnight 1t is all the work OF the


soul, to whom the body is slave; and shall


not the agony of mothers passion, who sees
| her babe, whose warm mouth had just LETT


her breast, hurried off by demon to hid


eous death, bear her limbs aloft wherever
there is dust to dust, till she reach that de-


vourng den, and fercer and more furious
far, in the passion of love, than any bird OF


prey that ever bathed its beak with bloed.


throttle the fends that with their heavy wings


would fain flap her down the cliffs, and


hold up her child in deliverance before the


eye of the All-Seeing God.


No stop-no stay-she knew not that she
drew her breath. Beneath her feet Provi-

hands strengthened every root. How was


she ever to descend That fear, then, but


once crossed her heart, as up-up-to
the little image made of her own flesh and


blood.


! "The God who holds me now from perish


ing-will not the same God save me when
my child is on my bosomi" Down come the
| fierce rushing of the eagles wings-each sa-
wage bird dashing close to her head, SO that


she saw the yellow of their wrathful eyes.
Al at once they quaed and were cowed.
Yelling they few off to the stump of an ash
iutting out of a cliff. thousand feet above
the cataract, and the Christian mother fall
| ing across the eyrie. in the midst of bones


and blood, clasped her chid--dcad-dead---


dead--no doubt; but unmangled and untorns


and swaddled up just as it was when she lay


it down asleep among the fresh hay in q


nook of the harvest field. OH what pangs


of blessedness transhxed her heart from


that faint feeble cry-'It lves-it lives-it


lives .'-and barring her bosom with loud


laughter, and eyes dry as stones, she felt the
lips of the unconscious innocent once more


mnrmuring at the fount of life and love -


"Oh thou great and thou dreadful God whi~
Their hast thou brought me, one of the most
sinful of thy creatures? Oh, save my soul,
lest it perish, even for thy own names sake
Oh Thou, who diedst to save sinners, have


mercy upon me Cliffs, chasms, blocks of


stones, and the skeletons of old trees--far-


far down--and dwindled into specks, thou


sand creatures of her own kind, stationary,


running to and fro Was that the sound of


the waterfall, or the faint roar of voices -


Is that her native strath and that tuft of
trees, does it contain the hut in which stands


the cradle of her childi Never more shall
it be rocked bv her foot Here must she


diet and when her breast is exhausted, her
, baby too! And those horrid beaks, and eyes,


and talons, and wings, will return, and her


child will be devoured at last, even within
!, the dead bosom that can protect it no more!
t Where, all this while, was Mark Steuart,
the sailor? Half way up the cliffs. But his
eve had got dim, his head dizzy, and his
heart sick-and he, who haG SO often reef
, ed the gallant sail, when at midnight
the coming of the gale was heard afar. COW
cred his face with his hands, and dared look
: no longer on the swimming heights. And
who will take care of my poor bed ridden
e mother" thought Hannah, whose soul, thro'
. the exhaustion of SO many passions, could
f no more retain in its grasp that hope which
: it had clutched in despair. A voice whis-
( pered Cod She looked round, expecting
to see an angel, but nothing moved except
/ a rotten branch, that, under Its own weight,
S broke off from the crumbing rock. Her
0 eye, by some secret sympathy of her soul
- with the nanimate object, watched its tall;
3 and it seemed to stop, not far off, on plat
n form. Her child was bound within her bo'
n som--she remembered not how or when
e but it was safe; and scarcely daring to open


her eyes, she slid down the shelving rocks,
d and found herself on small piece of firm
= root bound soil, with the top of bushes ap-
: pearing below. With fingers suddenly
s strengthened into the power of iron, she
: swung herself down by briar and broom, and
heather, and dwarf birch. There, ioos--
! ened stone fell over ledge. and no sound
g was heard, so profound was its fall There,
/ the shngle ratified down the scrags, and she
It hesitated not to follow.--Her feet bounded
Is against the huge stone that stopped them,
;, but she felt no pain. Her body was calous
t as the cliff. Steep as the wall of the house
i. was now the side of the precipice. But it
* was matted with ivy, Centuries old--long age
II dead, and without a single green leaf; bu'
le with thousands of arm thick stems petrlftd
At into the rock, and covering it as with trel-
r lice. She bound her babe to her neck, apt
t. with hands and feet clung to that feartu
J. ladder. Turning round her head and looking
lie down, 10! the whole population of the par
- prpat was thet, nultttude--on fh hpi

she entertained travellers, requested
nights lodging She eyed him with that
cold look of disapprobation which most peo-
pie assume when they imagine themselves
insulted, BY being supposed to exercise an
employment but one degree below their re-
al occupation in life assured him that he
had been misinformed--tha she did not keep
tavern, but that it was true, to oblige some
members of the legislature, she took mum.
Der of them into her family during the ces-
sion, chat she had four members osiCouncil,
and six of the House Of Representatives.
who then boarded with her-that all her
beds were full; and then betook herself to
her knitting with that intense application,
which expressed, as forcibly as action could
do, if you have concluded your business, the
sooner y you leave the house the better.-But
upon the Doctors wrapping his coat around
him, affecting to shyer with cold. and OBJ
serving it was very chilly weather she point
ed to chair, and gave him leave to warm
himself.


The entrance of her boarders precluded
all further conversation-coffce was soon
served, and the Doctor partook with the
family. To the coffee according to the
good old custom of the times, succeeded Il
slate Of pippins, pipes, and paper Of M'In-
tires best, when the whole family formed
cheerful smoking scmi-circle around the fire.
Perhaps no man ever possessed the colloqui-


al powers to a more fascinating degree, than
Doctor Franklin and never was there an oc-
casion, when he displayed those powers to
greater advantage than at this time. lie
! drew the attention Of the company by the
sodity of his modest remarks-instructing
them BY the varied, new, aud striking lights
in which he placed his subjects, and delight
ed them with apt and amusing anecdotes.
Thus employed, the hours passed tnerrily
alony until eight O'Clock when punctual to
moment, Mrs. Fran n ,unou u"red supper.
Busicd with her househod affairs she fam
cied the intruding stranger had quilted the
house Immediately after coffee, and 1t was
with diff 1t, she could restrain her resent


meut when She saw him without molesta-
tiou, seat himself at the table, with the free
dom of a member Of the family.


Immediately after supper, she called an
elderly gentleman, member of the Coun-
cii. in whom She was accua.omed to confde,
10 ,nther room--compl planned bitterly OF the
rudcn Is OF the strangcr---told the II amer
~ introduction to the house--observed
that he appeared like all outlandish man,


and she thought, had something very sus-


p1ous in his appearance, concluding by So


Letting her friends advice with respect TO


the wav in which she could most easily rid


herself Of his presence. The old gentleman


assured her, that the stranger was certainly


a Young man of education, and to all ap


pearance, gentleman, that, perhaps, being


in agreeable company, ne had paid no atten-


tion to the lateness of the hour; and ADVISED
her to call him aside, and repeat to him her


inability to lodge him. She accordingly sent
3 ,uitl, r
temper AS she conld command, recapltulat-


ed the situation of her family; observed that


it grew late, and mildly intimated that he


would do well to seek himself a lodging


The Doctor replied he would by no mean:


incommode her family; but that with hel


leave, he would smoke one pipe more with
her borders, and then retire.


He returned to the company, filled hi:


pipe, and with the first Whit, returned with


double force. He rccounted the hardships


he extolled the piety aud policy OF their an
cestors. A gentleman present menuohel
the subject of the days debate in the hous
of representatives. A bill had been intro


duced to extend the prerogatiyes OF the roy


al governor. The Doctor Immediately enter
: ed upon the suoject-supported the colonia
" rights with new and forcble arguments-w
familiar with the names of the infuentia
| men in the house, when Dudley was govern
or-rectcd their speeches, and applauae'
the noble defence Of the chamber rights.


During discourse SO appropriately inter
: esting to the company. no wonder the cloc'
; struck eleven unperceived by the del'ghte'
{ circle: and was it wonderful that the pa


tience of Mrs. Franklin grew quite exhaust


edl She now entered the room. and pefor


the whole company, with much warmth
/. addressed the Doctor; told him plainly, sh
IL thought herself imposed upon; observed tina
o it was true she was lone woman, but tina
It she had friends who would protect her, an
II concluded, bv insisting on his leaving tn
S house. The Doctor made slight apology
{ deliberately put on his great coat and ha
z took polite leave of the company. and ap
|, preached the street door, lighted by th
d maid and attended by the mistress.


: While the Doctor and his companions ha
If been enjoying themselves within, a most tire
" mendous snow storm, had, without, lille
: the streets knee deep; and no sooner ha
1t the maid lifted the latch, than roarln
d uortheaster forced open the door, extlnguisl
l. ed the light, and almost filled the entry wit


drifted snow and hail.-As soon as it We
e relighted the Doctor cast wotul look t.
d wards the door, and thus addressed h
is mother: My dear madam, can you turn m
e out in this dreadful storms l am strange

full articles.headline: INSTINCT.
full articles.article:
Doctor Benjamin Franklin, after the de-
cease of his father, returned to Boston, iii
order to paw his respects to his mother, who
resided in that city. He had been absent
some years, and at that period of life, when
the greatest and most rapid alteration IS


made in the human appearance, at a time


when the querulous voice OF the stripping


assumes the commanding tone OF the adult,


and smiling features of youth are succeeded


by the strong lines of manhood. The Doc


tor was sensible such was the alteration OF


his person, that his mother could not Know
him except bv that instinct, which 1t IS be-
lieved, can cause mothers heart TO beat


most violently in the presence ct child, and
point the maternal eve, with quick and sud
den glance, to beloved son.


To discover the existence, OF this u1Sfincl
by actual experience, the Doctor resolved
to introduce himself as a stranger, to ms
mother, and to watch, narrowly, for the
moment in which she should dicover her
son, and then to determine, with the cool
precision of the philosopher, whether that
dicovery was the effect of that instinct OF at
| fection--that intuitive love--that innate at
tachment. which is conjecturcd to cement
relatives of the same blood; and which, by


according the passions OF parent and CHILD
| like a well-tuned viol, would at the tlrs'
touch cause them to vibrate in unison and al


once evince that they were different chords
of the same instrument.


| On a sullen chilly day, in the month o.
January, in the afternoon, the Doctor knock

full articles.headline: HARMONY IN FAMILIES.
full articles.article:
Impartiality tends greatly to promote har-
mony in families. Hence the necessity OF
parents not manifesting any partiality to one
or more of their children. In the favored
child, it laws the foundation tor pride and
self-importance, and in the neglected one, 1t
raises Indignation if not hatred; whatever
NAV be the motives assigned for Partially,
parents must answer to the Judge OF all the
earth, for the sorrows and evils it produces,


Harmony in family will be greatly inter
rupted, should the father and mcther pursue
different systems in the management OF their
children. 1t is therefore necessary that they
adopt similar plan, otherwise one or the
other of them, and perhaps both, will lose
the esteem Of their children; obedience to
each is not to be expected, or the probabiil-
ty is, that bad habits and ihcoherent princl-
pies will be established.


In order to promote love and harmony
among children, one should not be allowed
to domineer over or tease the other. Nor
ought one to be praised at the expense OF
another. No envious comparison must DC
drawn. Children should not be allowed to
scoff at one who happens to be an offender
This practice destroys affection, and gives
rise to resentment and retaliation. lhey
should be taught to feel for one another when
in disgrace, and not be prohibited from III
terCclinp.

full articles.headline: A HEROINE,
full articles.article:
From Broughton's letters written in Nah
rata camp, we extract the following as
noble exception amid the visianes OF a
treacherous and distin. u ahetl people.


at was in one of these battallons that an
interesting young girl was discovered, about
a twelvemonth ago, who had served IN 1t Tor
two or three years as a Sipahec; in which
capacity she had acquired the favor OF her
supr riors, and the regard OF her comr Ides,
by her quiet and inofensve behaviour and
regular attention to the duties OF her sta
ton. 1t was obs, rived that she AWAY $
dressed her own dinner, and ate 1t. ana per
formed her ablutiuns, BY herself; but not
the slightest suspicion of her sex was IN
tertained, till about the time ! menrone1, /,
when it vas discovered by the curiosity OF d
young Sipahee, who followed her when She
went to bathe After this She continued to
serve for some months, reso' 'utcly declining
the patronage of the Baee. who proposed 70
receive her into his own family, as well As
the offers of Muha Raj to promote her i'll
the corps she belonged to. The affair soon
became the subject of general conversation
in the camp; and having expressed a
strong wish to see Jerusalem or Singh, the
name by which the Indian ID Eon went, one
of our Sipahccs, who was acquainted with
her, brought her to my tent. She appeared
to be about twenty two years ofage, was We
ry fair, and. though not handsome, possess
ed most interesting countenance. she
spoke freely of her profession and her i'm
mediate situation; but betrayed neither the
affected bashfuluess nor forward boldnes'
which such situation was likely to have
produced. And let it be recorded to the
honor of every party concerned, that iron
the moment when her sex was discovered
she met only with increased respect and at
tention from her comrades; not an ndividu
al presumed to utter word that might in
suit her, or breathing doubt that could at
feet her reputation. AT length her motiv
for enlsting and remaining in the seryic
was discovered.


An only brother was confined for debt d
Bopal, and this interesting young crcatur
had the courage to enroll herself as com
mon soldier, aud afterwards persisted in ex
posing her person to the dangers and dltt1
cuties of military life, with the generou
idea of raising money sufficient to lberat
this loved relation from confinement"

before the parlor fire. Although the board
ers appeared to conhde, perfectly, in the
strangers honesty, it was not so with Mrs.
Franklin. With suspicious caution she col
lected her silver spoons, pepper box, AND
porringer, from her closet; and after secur-
ing her parlor door, by sticking fork over
the latch, carried the plate to her chamber;
charged the negro man to sleep with his
clothes Onto take the great clever to bed
with him, and to awaken and selze the va
grant at the first noise he made in attempt
ing to plunder the house. Having thus TAX
en- every precaution, she retired to bed with
her maid, whom she compelled to sleep in
her room.


Mrs Franklin rose before the sun, rous.
ed her domestics, unfastened the parlor door
with timid caution, and was agreeably sur
priscd to find her guest quietly sleeping on
his own chair. A sudden transition from ex-
tremc distrust to perfect confidence, was nat
ural. She awak encd him with a cheerful good
morning; inquired how he rested; invited him
to partake of her breakfast, which was al
ways served previous to that of her board
ers And pray sir, said the lady, as she sip
ped her chocolate, as you appear to be
stranger here, to what distant country do
you belongl !, madam, belong to the city
of PhiiQdrlhkiG. At the mention of Phiia-
phia the Doctor declared he, for the first
time, perceived any emotion in her. Phil
adelphia said she, and all the mother suf-
fused the eye: if you live in Philadelphia,
perhaps you kaow our Ben. Who madam
Why Ben Franklin--my Ben. What, said
the Doctor, is Ben Franklin the printer
your son, why, he is my most intimate
friend he and lodge in the same room.
oh God forgive me, exclaimed the old la
dy, raising her watery eyes to heaven--and
have suffered an acquaintance of my Ben
ny to sleep in this hard chair, while my
self rested on good bed


How the Doctor discovered himself to his
mother he has not informed us: but from the
above experiment, he was firmly convinced,
and was often afterwards heard to declare,
that naturaf affection does not exist.

full articles.headline:
From HE Christian Register.
THE SNOW FLAKES.
full articles.article:
Ye are falling to earth from your ancient domaln'


We arc shrouding her bosom in triumph again;


We are sweeping on with the wintry blast!


Yc are ruling all-but your sway cannot last
Pile ye up! pile ye up your crest OF white
As ye fall, and mingle your wreaths OF lie;
lYe are welcome, welcome to rest on the earth'
But tell us the place of your icy birth
ave come from those clouds that are ioatne on
high,


Still tlarkning the face ofthe cold blue sky'


The chill breath of winter but scattered our tram,
10 ningle anew on this earthly domain
We would gladly descend in unerring array,
But the tempests of heaven will blow us astray!
We must follow them still where'er they may
guide,
To the shade that we love OF the sunny hill side.
Like man we remain but moment below,
And are subject like him to each blast that may
blow;


Like him we ascend rejoicing on high,
To the place Of our birth in the sapphire sky. .

full articles.headline:
spD-H1rsaYa o

The tollo,oing beautiful lines, are from The "Mi-


nerru" Of 1925.
full articles.article:
Tile follo,viag beautiful lines, are from the "Ni-


nerru' Of 1925.
When Hopes fairy fingers are straylng


o,+rthe chords ofthe youthful heart,
And fancy in prospects displaying


The bliss that new years may lmpart;
When sweet feelings are ever unsprlnging,


And the pulses all ioyou,ly beat,
When each day a new treasure is bringing,


Oh. then indeed life is most sweet!
When the torch of affection Just lighted,


Burns bright on the altar Of truth,
Ere the cold, selfish world yet has blighted


One innocent feeling ofyorlth,
When earth seems a garden unfading,


When flowers cEngaround our glad feet,
When no cloud our bright heaven is shading,


Oh then indeed is life most sweet!
When the cold breath of sorrow is sweeping
Ger the chords of the youthful heart,
And the youthful eye dmmcd with strange weep
ing,


Sees the visions of fancy departs
When the bloom of young feelingis dying;
And the breast throbs with passions fierce
strife,
when our sad DAYS are wasted in signing,
Who then can find sweetness in life!
When unkindness or coldncss has faded,


The pure undeiiled light OF love,
And the lnists Of the cold world have shaded
The dreams that around our hearts move;
When earth seems wide waste OF sorrow,
No longer with bright blessings rife,
When we look but for clouds on each morrow


Who then can find sweetness in life

full articles.headline:
From the Museum.
HANNAH LAMOND AND The EAGLE
full articles.article:
Some people have trick Of describing in
cidents as having happened within their
own observation, when, in fact, they were
at the time lying asleep in bed, and disturb
ing the whole house with their dormitory.-
Such is too often the character of the eve


witnesses OF the present age. Now, would
not claim personal acquaintance with an in-
cident had not seen--no, not for fifty gum
eas per sheet; and, therefore, l warn the
reader not to believe the following little


story about an eagle and child (by the way,
that is the Derby crest, and favorite sign of
inns in the north of England on the alleged


authority of the writer of this article. i
tell the tale as twas told to me- by the
schoolmaster of the parish alluded to above,


and if the incident never occurred, then must


he have been one of the greatest and most


gratuitous of liars that ever taught the


young idea how to shoot For my single


self am by nature credulous Many ex-
traerdinary things happen in this life, and


though seeing is believing so likewise 'be.


licving is seeing as every one must allow


who reads the following pages of this Mag


azine.


".llmost all the people in the parish were


leading in their meadow hay (thcrc were not
in all its ten miles aquare, twenty acres of


rye grass) on the same day of midsummer,


so driving was the sun and wind--and huged
heapcd up wains, that almost hid from view
the horses that drew them along the sward
beginning to get green with another growth,


were moving in all directions towards the


snug farm yards. Never had the parish be-


fore seemed so populous. Jocund was the


balmy air, with laughter, whistle and song.
But the Tregomers threw the shadow OF


"one O. clock" OH the green dial face of the


earth-the horses we're unyokeG and took
instantly to grazing-groups ofmen, women,


lads. lassies and children, collected under


grove, and bush, and hedgerow-graces


were pronounced, some of them rather too
tedious, in presence of the mantling milk
cans, bullion bars of butter, and cracking
cakes; and the Great Being who gave them
, that day their daily food, looked down from
=, his Eternal Throne, well pleased with the
piety of his thankful creatures.


t The Great Golden Eagle, the pride and
the pest of the parish, stopped down and a.
| way with something in his talons. One sin.
. gle sudden female strickland then shout:
, and outcries as if church spire had tum
F., bled down on a congregation at sacrament
"Hannah Lamond's bairn!" Hannah La
monds bairu! !" was the loCd fast spreading


cry.-" The Eagles ta'en off Hannah La
| mopd's bairn!'' And many hundred fee
were in another instant hurrying toward
! the mountain. Two miles of hill and dale
/ and copse, and shinglc, and many intersect
2 ing brooks lay between; but in an incredi
! bly, short time the foot OF the mountain wa
. alive with people. The eyrie was vel
S known, and both the old birds were visibl
= on the rocklege. But who shall scale tina
S dizzy cliff, which Mark Steuart, the sailor
e who had been at the storming of many tort
r attempted in vain. All kept gazing, weep
n ing, wringing of hands, rooted to tn
Z: ground, or running backward and forwards
n like so many ants essaying their new wing
t in discontinue.


!: "What's the use o. ony puir huma
1t meanss We hae no power but in prayer !
j, and many knelt down-fathers and mother
t; thinking of their own babes-as It they woul
IS force the deaf heavens to hear!


Hannah Lamond had all this while bee
e sitting on rock, with face perfectly white
t. and eyes like those of mad person, tixe
d on the eyrie. Nobody had noticed her; TO
ID strong as all sympathies with her had bee
ir at the swoop of the Eagle, they were no

the touch OF unkindness, delicate flower,
which indifference will chill, and sn$hicfon
blast. 1t must be watered with showers OF
tender aGfction: expanded with the glow OF
attention, and guarded by the impresnaoie
barrier Of unshaken confdence. Thus ma
tured, it blooms with fragrance IN every sea
son of life, and sweetens even the loneliness
of declining years.

full articles.headline:
Selected for the Wilmingtonian.


MILLENNIUM.
full articles.article:
ScleCteu lOT Tic w ihHihS soihAH'


MILLENNIUM.
Look up, ye saints, with sweet surprise;
Toward the joyful coming day,
When Jesus shall descend the skies,
And form bright and dazzling ray.
Nations shall in day be born,
-, And swift, like doves, to Jesus fly;
iae church shall know no clouds return,
nor sorrows mixing with their JOY.
The Lion and the Lamb shall feed
together in his peaceful reign;
ana Zion, blest with heavily bread,
ofpnching wants no more complain
me Jew, the Greek, the bond, the free,
H., snall boast their sep'rate rights no morei
~, JON IN sweetest harmony,


ineir Lord, their Saviour to adore.
nus aus nil thousand years be past,
snall holiness and peace prevail;


.uev'ry knee shall bow to Christ,


ana ev'ry tongue shall Jesus hail.
Isn wa the redeem'd shall mount on high,
Ana Aa"ere Their deliv'ring Prince is gone;


Toh rahhgeis at his word shall fly,
~SO'ess them with the .conq'ror's crown.

full articles.headline: Selected for the Wiimingtonian.
full articles.article:
When SHOWS descend, and robe the fields


In winters bright array;


Touch'd byt the sun, the lustre fades,


And weeps itself away.


When spring appears; when violets blow,
And shed a rich perfume;


How soon the fragrance breaths its last
How short lived is the bloom!
Fresh in the morn, the summer rose
Hangs whitening ereftis noon;
Wescarce enjoy the balmy gift,
But mourn the pleasures gone.
euch are the charms that flush the cheek,
And sparkle in the eye:
Sofrom the vely-6nsh'd form,
The trancient graces fly. AN. c.

full articles.headline: MATRIMONY.
full articles.article:
Aa.S1eat portion Of the wrethedness which
sua,.s ueh embittered married life, l am per-
syiasao mas originated in the negligence OF
% 6's. . Connubisl happiness is thing OF


y texture to be handled roughly. 1t

Son, and the Holy GhoSt,e and OH utterln6


these words, she few off through the heak-


ers, and over the huge stones-up-up-up


faster than ever huntsman ran into the


death-fearless as goat playing among the


precipices. No one doubted, no one could
doubt, but that she would soon be dashed to


pieces. But have not people who walk in


their sleep obedient to the mysterious guild


ance of dreams, clomb the walls of old ruins,


and found footing, even in decrepitude, along


the edge of the unguarded battlemeDts and


down dilapidated staircases, deep as draw


wells, or coal pits, and returned with open,


fixed, and unseeing eyes, unharu ed to their
beds at midnight 1t is all the work OF the


soul, to whom the body is slave; and shall


not the agony of mothers passion, who sees
| her babe, whose warm mouth had just LETT


her breast, hurried off by demon to hid


eous death, bear her limbs aloft wherever
there is dust to dust, till she reach that de-


vourng den, and fercer and more furious
far, in the passion of love, than any bird OF


prey that ever bathed its beak with bloed.


throttle the fends that with their heavy wings


would fain flap her down the cliffs, and


hold up her child in deliverance before the


eye of the All-Seeing God.


No stop-no stay-she knew not that she
drew her breath. Beneath her feet Provi-
QeDCe IdSIeneu every lOoSC oto''Ss anu W IVA


hands strengthened every root. How was


she ever to descend That fear, then, but


once crossed her heart, as up-up-to
the little image made of her own flesh and


blood.


! "The God who holds me now from perish


ing-will not the same God save me when
my child is on my bosomi" Down come the
| fierce rushing of the eagles wings-each sa-
wage bird dashing close to her head, SO that


she saw the yellow of their wrathful eyes.
Al at once they quaed and were cowed.
Yelling they few off to the stump of an ash
iutting out of a cliff. thousand feet above
the cataract, and the Christian mother fall
| ing across the eyrie. in the midst of bones


and blood, clasped her chid--dcad-dead---


dead--no doubt; but unmangled and untorns


and swaddled up just as it was when she lay


it down asleep among the fresh hay in q


nook of the harvest field. OH what pangs


of blessedness transhxed her heart from


that faint feeble cry-'It lves-it lives-it


lives .'-and barring her bosom with loud


laughter, and eyes dry as stones, she felt the
lips of the unconscious innocent once more


mnrmuring at the fount of life and love -


"Oh thou great and thou dreadful God whi~
Their hast thou brought me, one of the most
sinful of thy creatures? Oh, save my soul,
lest it perish, even for thy own names sake
Oh Thou, who diedst to save sinners, have


mercy upon me Cliffs, chasms, blocks of


stones, and the skeletons of old trees--far-


far down--and dwindled into specks, thou


sand creatures of her own kind, stationary,


running to and fro Was that the sound of


the waterfall, or the faint roar of voices -


Is that her native strath and that tuft of
trees, does it contain the hut in which stands


the cradle of her childi Never more shall
it be rocked bv her foot Here must she


diet and when her breast is exhausted, her
, baby too! And those horrid beaks, and eyes,


and talons, and wings, will return, and her


child will be devoured at last, even within
!, the dead bosom that can protect it no more!
t Where, all this while, was Mark Steuart,
the sailor? Half way up the cliffs. But his
eve had got dim, his head dizzy, and his
heart sick-and he, who haG SO often reef
, ed the gallant sail, when at midnight
the coming of the gale was heard afar. COW
cred his face with his hands, and dared look
: no longer on the swimming heights. And
who will take care of my poor bed ridden
e mother" thought Hannah, whose soul, thro'
. the exhaustion of SO many passions, could
f no more retain in its grasp that hope which
: it had clutched in despair. A voice whis-
( pered Cod She looked round, expecting
to see an angel, but nothing moved except
/ a rotten branch, that, under Its own weight,
S broke off from the crumbing rock. Her
0 eye, by some secret sympathy of her soul
- with the nanimate object, watched its tall;
3 and it seemed to stop, not far off, on plat
n form. Her child was bound within her bo'
n som--she remembered not how or when
e but it was safe; and scarcely daring to open


her eyes, she slid down the shelving rocks,
d and found herself on small piece of firm
= root bound soil, with the top of bushes ap-
: pearing below. With fingers suddenly
s strengthened into the power of iron, she
: swung herself down by briar and broom, and
heather, and dwarf birch. There, ioos--
! ened stone fell over ledge. and no sound
g was heard, so profound was its fall There,
/ the shngle ratified down the scrags, and she
It hesitated not to follow.--Her feet bounded
Is against the huge stone that stopped them,
;, but she felt no pain. Her body was calous
t as the cliff. Steep as the wall of the house
i. was now the side of the precipice. But it
* was matted with ivy, Centuries old--long age
II dead, and without a single green leaf; bu'
le with thousands of arm thick stems petrlftd
At into the rock, and covering it as with trel-
r lice. She bound her babe to her neck, apt
t. with hands and feet clung to that feartu
J. ladder. Turning round her head and looking
lie down, 10! the whole population of the par
- prpat was thet, nultttude--on fh hpi

full articles.headline: FEBRUARY Is, 1927
full articles.article:
she entertained travellers, requested
nights lodging She eyed him with that
cold look of disapprobation which most peo-
pie assume when they imagine themselves
insulted, BY being supposed to exercise an
employment but one degree below their re-
al occupation in life assured him that he
had been misinformed--tha she did not keep
tavern, but that it was true, to oblige some
members of the legislature, she took mum.
Der of them into her family during the ces-
sion, chat she had four members osiCouncil,
and six of the House Of Representatives.
who then boarded with her-that all her
beds were full; and then betook herself to
her knitting with that intense application,
which expressed, as forcibly as action could
do, if you have concluded your business, the
sooner y you leave the house the better.-But
upon the Doctors wrapping his coat around
him, affecting to shyer with cold. and OBJ
serving it was very chilly weather she point
ed to chair, and gave him leave to warm
himself.


The entrance of her boarders precluded
all further conversation-coffce was soon
served, and the Doctor partook with the
family. To the coffee according to the
good old custom of the times, succeeded Il
slate Of pippins, pipes, and paper Of M'In-
tires best, when the whole family formed
cheerful smoking scmi-circle around the fire.
Perhaps no man ever possessed the colloqui-


al powers to a more fascinating degree, than
Doctor Franklin and never was there an oc-
casion, when he displayed those powers to
greater advantage than at this time. lie
! drew the attention Of the company by the
sodity of his modest remarks-instructing
them BY the varied, new, aud striking lights
in which he placed his subjects, and delight
ed them with apt and amusing anecdotes.
Thus employed, the hours passed tnerrily
alony until eight O'Clock when punctual to
moment, Mrs. Fran n ,unou u"red supper.
Busicd with her househod affairs she fam
cied the intruding stranger had quilted the
house Immediately after coffee, and 1t was
with diff 1t, she could restrain her resent


meut when She saw him without molesta-
tiou, seat himself at the table, with the free
dom of a member Of the family.


Immediately after supper, she called an
elderly gentleman, member of the Coun-
cii. in whom She was accua.omed to confde,
10 ,nther room--compl planned bitterly OF the
rudcn Is OF the strangcr---told the II amer
~ introduction to the house--observed
that he appeared like all outlandish man,


and she thought, had something very sus-


p1ous in his appearance, concluding by So


Letting her friends advice with respect TO


the wav in which she could most easily rid


herself Of his presence. The old gentleman


assured her, that the stranger was certainly


a Young man of education, and to all ap


pearance, gentleman, that, perhaps, being


in agreeable company, ne had paid no atten-


tion to the lateness of the hour; and ADVISED
her to call him aside, and repeat to him her


inability to lodge him. She accordingly sent
3 ,uitl, r
temper AS she conld command, recapltulat-


ed the situation of her family; observed that


it grew late, and mildly intimated that he


would do well to seek himself a lodging


The Doctor replied he would by no mean:


incommode her family; but that with hel


leave, he would smoke one pipe more with
her borders, and then retire.


He returned to the company, filled hi:


pipe, and with the first Whit, returned with


double force. He rccounted the hardships


he extolled the piety aud policy OF their an
cestors. A gentleman present menuohel
the subject of the days debate in the hous
of representatives. A bill had been intro


duced to extend the prerogatiyes OF the roy


al governor. The Doctor Immediately enter
: ed upon the suoject-supported the colonia
" rights with new and forcble arguments-w
familiar with the names of the infuentia
| men in the house, when Dudley was govern
or-rectcd their speeches, and applauae'
the noble defence Of the chamber rights.


During discourse SO appropriately inter
: esting to the company. no wonder the cloc'
; struck eleven unperceived by the del'ghte'
{ circle: and was it wonderful that the pa


tience of Mrs. Franklin grew quite exhaust


edl She now entered the room. and pefor


the whole company, with much warmth
/. addressed the Doctor; told him plainly, sh
IL thought herself imposed upon; observed tina
o it was true she was lone woman, but tina
It she had friends who would protect her, an
II concluded, bv insisting on his leaving tn
S house. The Doctor made slight apology
{ deliberately put on his great coat and ha
z took polite leave of the company. and ap
|, preached the street door, lighted by th
d maid and attended by the mistress.


: While the Doctor and his companions ha
If been enjoying themselves within, a most tire
" mendous snow storm, had, without, lille
: the streets knee deep; and no sooner ha
1t the maid lifted the latch, than roarln
d uortheaster forced open the door, extlnguisl
l. ed the light, and almost filled the entry wit


drifted snow and hail.-As soon as it We
e relighted the Doctor cast wotul look t.
d wards the door, and thus addressed h
is mother: My dear madam, can you turn m
e out in this dreadful storms l am strange
,r in this town, and shall certainly perish
